pullRequest.body:
Replicate `Data/Fintype/Option`, but yield non-truncated data.

First chunk of #12648

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ofIsEmpty`

`+ recEmptyOption_of_card_pos`
`+ recOnEmptyOption`
`+ up_equiv`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

This PR is defining data using tactics. To prove that the resulting declarations are usable, can you prove the basic equation lemmas for them, i.e. write that API showing that the definitions produce what you expect them to produce for the empty and option inputs?

> This PR is defining data using tactics. To prove that the resulting declarations are usable, can you prove the basic equation lemmas for them, i.e. write that API showing that the definitions produce what you expect them to produce for the empty and option inputs?

Thank you for bringing this to my attention! I've re-written the definition, but since it's a bit awkward to reduce, the lemmas you mentioned are now provided, as well. I would've loved to state them in terms of `IsEmpty` and `NonEmpty`, but that would've made the required proof arguments on the RHSs even more bloated. Since I didn't want those derivations to go to waste, though, I've added them to `FinEnum.lean`. I fear that I might've gone a bit overboard in providing `FinEnum` instances for all `IsEmpty` and `Unique` types, as that's what leads to `simp` now finding more lemmas via typeclass inference.

Are there any recommendations on how to deal with those? Or should I just scrap the generic instances? I don't think the remark that accompanies [`Fintype.ofIsEmpty`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Fintype/Basic.html#Fintype.ofIsEmpty) is applicable here, due to `IsEmpty Î± â†’ Unique (FinEnum Î±)` implying there cannot be two observably conflicting `FinEnum Î±` instances. Though I would suppose the same goes for `Fintype Î±`, so maybe I don't understand the remark thoroughly enoughâ€¦

You have correctly argued that there couldn't be two propositionally distinct instances of `FinEnum Î±` when `IsEmpty Î±` (or more generally `Subsingleton Î±`), but there could still *definitionally* distinct instances. Try checking whether the two instances for `Fin 0` (the one coming from `IsEmpty (Fin 0)` and the one coming from `Fin n`) are definitionally equal by doing `example : the_first_instance = the_second_instance := rfl`.

> You have correctly argued that there couldn't be two propositionally distinct instances of `FinEnum Î±` when `IsEmpty Î±` (or more generally `Subsingleton Î±`), but there could still _definitionally_ distinct instances. Try checking whether the two instances for `Fin 0` (the one coming from `IsEmpty (Fin 0)` and the one coming from `Fin n`) are definitionally equal by doing `example : the_first_instance = the_second_instance := rfl`.

Naturally, the two instances were not definitionally equal. Although I believe that the instances defined here are particularly inelegant, not even

```lean
#check (rfl : ofIsEmpty (Î± := Fin 0) = âŸ¨0, Equiv.refl (Fin 0)âŸ©)
```

goes through. Anyway, the instances are now not haphazardously registered anymore.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
@YaelDillies could you please check if I've interpreted your ULift simp lemmata correctly?
I would avoid mentioning `ULift.instFinEnum` directly. Apart from that, ðŸ‘

> I would avoid mentioning `ULift.instFinEnum` directly.

`equiv.symm` alone does not suffice, as `equiv` will want to refer to `Î±` instead of `ULift Î±`.

`(equiv (Î± := ULift Î±)).symm` does work; would you like me to use that instead?
Yes please!

Thank you for the PR!

maintainer delegate
Generally, can you try deducing your lemmas from the corresponding `Fintype` ones? We have `FinEnum.instFintype` (which should really be called `FinEnum.toFintype`)

Thank you for the PR!

maintainer delegate

```suggestion

end FinEnum
```
Can this cross-ref `Fintype.induction_empty_option` and `Fintype.truncRecEmptyOption` (or maybe the whole `Data.Fintype.Option` file)?

```suggestion
    (finChoice : (n : â„•) â†’ Fin (n + 1))
    (congr : {Î± Î² : Type u} â†’ (_ : FinEnum Î±) â†’ (_ : FinEnum Î²) â†’ card Î² = card Î± â†’ P Î± â†’ P Î² )
    (empty : P PEmpty.{u + 1})
    (option : {Î± : Type u} â†’ FinEnum Î± â†’ P Î± â†’ P (Option Î±))
```
to match the naming convention

```suggestion
For an empty type, the recursion principle evaluates to whatever `of_equiv`
```

```suggestion
theorem card_unique {Î± : Type u} (eâ‚ eâ‚‚ : FinEnum Î±) : eâ‚.card = eâ‚‚.card :=
```
maybe?

```suggestion
theorem card_eq_zero {Î± : Type u} [FinEnum Î±] [IsEmpty Î±] : card Î± = 0 :=
```
to match `Fintype.card_eq_zero`
Can you also write the analogue of `Fintype.card_eq_zero_iff`?

This is a bit weird given that the predecessor is explicitly given as `card Î± - 1`. The idiomatic way of finding the predecessor of `a` is not to inhabit `{n : â„• // a = n + 1}` but rather to prove `0 < a` and use `a - 1`. Hence I would suggest
```suggestion
lemma card_pos {Î± : Type*} [FinEnum Î±] [Nonempty Î±] : 0 < card Î± := sorry
lemma card_ne_zero {Î± : Type*} [FinEnum Î±] [Nonempty Î±] : card Î± â‰  0 := card_pos.ne'
```

```suggestion
theorem card_eq_one (Î± : Type u) [FinEnum Î±] [Unique Î±] : card Î± = 1 :=
```
Annoyingly, the analogous lemma here is the misnamed `Fintype.card_unique`...

```suggestion
instance _root_.ULift.instFinEnum [FinEnum Î±] : FinEnum (ULift Î±) :=
```

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem card_ulift [FinEnum (ULift Î±)] [FinEnum Î±] : card (ULift Î±) = card Î± :=
```

```suggestion
section ULift
variable [FinEnum Î±] (i : Fin (card Î±))

@[simp] lemma up_equiv : ULift.up (equiv i) = equiv i := rfl
@[simp] lemma down_equiv : (equiv i).down = equiv i := rfl
@[simp] lemma up_equiv_symm : ULift.up (equiv.symm i) = equiv.symm i := rfl
@[simp] lemma down_equiv_symm : (equiv.symm i).down = equiv.symm i := rfl

end ULift
```

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem card_fin {n} [FinEnum (Fin n)] : card (Fin n) = n := Fin.equiv_iff_eq.mp âŸ¨equiv.symmâŸ©
```

```suggestion
theorem card_eq_fintypeCard {Î± : Type u} [FinEnum Î±] [Fintype Î±] : card Î± = Fintype.card Î± :=
```

```suggestion
  insertNone Î± (Fin.last _)
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/FinEnum): Option instance and Type recursor

source.title: feat(Computability): introduce Generalised NFA as bridge to Regular Expression
